examples.en: This year's annual convention came to a successful end.
examples.ja: 今年の年次大会は無事終了いたしました。

examples.en: That information was in the annual report mailed to stockholders.
examples.ja: その情報は株主に郵送された年次報告書に記載されていました。

examples.en: At our company, unused yearly paid leave cannot be carried forward to the following year.
examples.ja: 当社では、未消化の年次休暇は次の年に繰り越すことができません。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>year</kanji> that is <kanji>next</kanji> is coming up. What will you do in the year that is next that you did this year too? What do you do that is <vocabulary>annual</vocabulary>?

年次 is a formal term typically used in business settings, such as in 年次報告書 (annual report) or 年次休暇 (annual leave).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It's said that what Adam and Eve ate in the Garden of Eden might have been a banana instead of an apple.
examples.ja: エデンの園でアダムとイブが食べたのは、実はリンゴじゃなくてバナナだったかもしれないんだって。

examples.en: I had a part-time job where I packed apples in boxes at an apple orchard.
examples.ja: リンゴ園でリンゴを箱づめするアルバイトをしていました。

examples.en: All of the teachers at our preschool are really good teachers.
examples.ja: うちの園の先生たちは、みんな良い先生ばかりです。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

This word is generally used in the names of gardens, like エデンの園 and 桜の園. It's also used in phrases like 学びの園, which means "school" and carries the connotation of being a haven for learning.
reading_mnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Which <vocabulary>garden</vocabulary> is the Garden of Eden? <reading>その</reading> garden! That garden right next to you is the Garden of Eden!

It can also use the on'yomi, though, which you've already learned. When it takes the on'yomi and is used as a standalone word, it usually refers to some kind of institution, like a 幼稚園.

examples.en: I heard that company is trying to hamper Tofugu's success.
examples.ja: あの会社は、トーフグの成功を妨げようとしているらしい。

examples.en: You should get rid of things that hinder productivity.
examples.ja: 生産性を妨げるものは、すててしまった方がいいよ。

examples.en: I don’t understand why people try to prevent aliens from reaching the earth.
examples.ja: どうして人々は宇宙人が地球にやってくる事を妨げようとするのか理解できません。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>obstruct</kanji>, so what is the verb vocab version? It's <vocabulary>to obstruct</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You try <vocabulary>to obstruct</vocabulary> a woman coming your way (see kanji). As she gets close, she roars, "I am <reading>Sama(n)tha</reading>!" (さまた) You shall let me pass!" You don't argue with Samanthas. Get out of her way!

examples.en: Isn’t this a really beautiful mountain stream?
examples.ja: とても美しい沢ですね。

examples.en: Many creatures such as freshwater crabs live in this stream.
examples.ja: この沢には沢ガニなど、たくさんの生き物が住んでいます。

examples.en: I like walking while listening to the sound of the stream.
examples.ja: 沢の音を聞きながら歩くのが好きなんです。

examples.en: I saw a gigantic alligator near a swamp in Florida.
examples.ja: フロリダのとある沢のほとりで、巨大なワニを見ました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word share the meaning of <vocabulary>swamp</vocabulary>, but this word is primarily used to mean <vocabulary>mountain stream</vocabulary>. Think of it this way, the water for a swamp has to come from somewhere right? It starts out up in the mountains and drains out into a swamp in the valley. The life cycle of a mountain stream into a swamp!
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: The beginning of the word <vocabulary>swamp</vocabulary> is actually pretty similar to this word's reading. さわ = "swa"? I'd say it's close enough to make a mnemonic out of in your head.

examples.en: It seems like Ichiro is in a slump this season, wouldn't you say?
examples.ja: イチローは今季は不振なようだね。

examples.en: I've been experiencing a loss of appetite recently.
examples.ja: 最近、食欲不振が続いてるんです。

examples.en: I'm feeling down due to the business' poor performance, and it's causing me to lose my appetite.
examples.ja: 業績不振で落ちこんでいて、食欲不振になっているんです。

examples.en: My CD was suffering from a slump in sales for a little while, but since being introduced on the radio, sales are rising again this month.
examples.ja: 私のCDはしばらく売上不振に苦しんでいたが、ラジオで紹介されてから今月は売上げが上昇しています。

meaning_mnemonic:
If something does <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>shake</kanji>, it’s probably in <vocabulary>a slump</vocabulary>. If nothing’s shaking, things must be <vocabulary>sluggish</vocabulary>.

不振 is used for times when things are slower or worse than usual. For example, 業績不振 is when a business isn’t doing as well as it usually does, and 食欲不振 is when you don't feel like eating as much as you normally would.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I am having trouble because my four-year-old daughter imitates everything she sees.
examples.ja: 四歳になる娘が、見るもの全てを真似するので困っています。

meaning_mnemonic: You're taking <kanji>reality</kanji> and trying to <kanji>resemble</kanji> it. To do this, you have to do an <vocabulary>imitation</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>mimicry</vocabulary>, or an <vocabulary>impersonation</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi reading for 真 and an irregular reading for 似. You've already learned the reading for 真, but here's a mnemonic to help you with 似:

What are you doing an <vocabulary>imitation</vocabulary> of? A horse! You gallop around <reading>neigh</reading>ing (ね) at the top of your lungs! That's a pretty good imitation.

examples.en: I've put up a simple tent for now.
examples.ja: とりあえず、簡易のテントを張っておいたよ。

examples.en: It's a pretty simple pattern, but I made a fundoshi.
examples.ja: かなり簡易な作りですが、フンドシを作ってみました。

examples.en: If you want to sleep over at our place, we have a cot.
examples.ja: もしうちに泊まりたいなら、簡易ベッドがあるよ。

meaning_mnemonic: It has <kanji>simplicity</kanji> and is <kanji>easy</kanji>. Whatever it is, it is <vocabulary>simple</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>easy</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’m editing a document summary in the office right now.
examples.ja: 今オフィスで資料の要約を編集しているところよ。

meaning_mnemonic: 編集 is <kanji>edit</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to edit</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Scientists say that space is one giant vacuum, right? So why don’t we just use that to clean our carpets?
examples.ja: 科学者は、宇宙はある巨大な掃除機だと言うでしょ？だったら、それをカーペットを掃除するのに使ったらいいんじゃない？？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>cleaning</kanji> (掃除) <kanji>machine</kanji> is a <vocabulary>vacuum cleaner</vocabulary>. Suck that dirt up!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Around what time are you planning to take a walk?
examples.ja: 何時くらいに散歩する予定なんですか？

examples.en: I try to take a walk every day for my health.
examples.ja: 健康のために毎日散歩するようにしています。

examples.en: I like to think while I'm on a walk.
examples.ja: 私は散歩しながら、考え事をするのが好きなんです。

examples.en: My wife wants me to leave work early and take the dog for a walk today. Is that okay with you?
examples.ja: 妻が、今日は早目に仕事を切り上げて犬を散歩させてほしいと言っているのですが、よろしいでしょうか。

meaning_mnemonic: 散歩 is "a walk." Make that into a verb and you have <vocabulary>to go for a walk</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to go for a stroll</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It will help to know 散歩 as well.

examples.en: That left‐handed pitcher made a brilliant major league debut.
examples.ja: その左利きの投手は、大リーグで華々しいデビューを飾りました。

meaning_mnemonic: 華やか is "showy." Now we're doubling it, making it doubly showy. If you make something showy enough, it becomes <vocabulary>gorgeous</vocabulary>, but it also becomes pretty <vocabulary>flamboyant</vocabulary>. So, so, so flamboyant.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 華やか. Note the second はな becomes ばな, to be <reading>はなばな</reading>しい.

examples.en: She managed to do well on those tricky jobs... except for that.
examples.ja: 彼女は厄介な仕事をうまくやってのけた…あることを除いて、だが。

meaning_mnemonic: 除く is "to exclude." This is the te-form, and it means "except." So, something like "please get everything except broccoli," because who wants broccoli?
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 除く. It's just the te-form of it.

examples.en: If you live next to a graveyard, ghosts might knock on your door.
examples.ja: 墓場の隣に住んだら、お化けがドアをノックすることもあるかもしれない。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>grave</kanji> <kanji>location</kanji> is a place where there are graves. It is a <vocabulary>graveyard</vocabulary>.

This word is more direct and informal than 墓地, so using 墓場 for an actual cemetery might come off as disrespectful. It's commonly used in phrases like ゆりかごから墓場まで (from the cradle to the grave) or 墓場まで持っていく (take a secret to the grave).
reading_mnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi for both kanji, which is fairly unusual, but then graveyards are unusual and special places. You've learned both of these readings before, so you should be able to read this on your own, but here's a reminder just in case:

This <vocabulary>graveyard</vocabulary> is only for <reading>hacker</reading>s (はか) who say "<reading>baa</reading>" (ば). In other words, dead hacker sheep. Many were anti-establishment types who leaked classified info to the public, then died in mysterious circumstances. Today, hackers the world over visit this graveyard and baa before the graves to pay their respects. Rest in fleece, comrades! Baa!

examples.en: I really like the time-lapse photography on this magazine’s cover.
examples.ja: この雑誌の表紙のインターバル撮影された写真すごい好きかも。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Random</kanji> <kanji>magazine</kanji> is pretty much all magazines. Just a bunch of random stuff inside, making it a <vocabulary>magazine</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: She really aced the job interview even though it was just for a ticket window position.
examples.ja: 窓口の仕事ではあったが、彼女はその面接をとてもうまくこなした。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>window</kanji> <kanji>mouth</kanji> is where you go to buy tickets out of the window. You know how there's those windows with holes in them, or the window is the hole itself? That's the kind of <vocabulary>ticket window</vocabulary> I'm talking about.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the readings for 窓 and the reading for 口.

examples.en: What’s this window made of?
examples.ja: この窓は何で作られているんですか。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji reading you learned.

examples.en: I haven’t decided if I’ll watch the video or not yet.
examples.ja: そのビデオを見るか否か、まだ決めきれていない。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Note that 否 (いな) is very formal and somewhat archaic. Today, it's most commonly used in the expression 〜か否か (whether… or <vocabulary>not</vocabulary>).
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Instead of saying "no" you say "na," and instead of saying "na" you say <reading>いな</reading>. 

Note that 否 can also be read いや, which is a common way to say “no” in modern Japanese, but that reading is almost always written in kana.

examples.en: The actress denied that she was on a diet.
examples.ja: その女優はダイエット中であることを否定した。

examples.en: I completely lost motivation, as the president denied everything I do.
examples.ja: 社長にやる事なす事全てを否定されて、やる気を完全に失ったよ。

examples.en: I can't always translate double negative sentences well.
examples.ja: 二重否定の文はいつも上手く訳せないんです。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>No</kanji>! I will not <kanji>determine</kanji> that. In fact, I <vocabulary>deny</vocabulary> it. This is my <vocabulary>denial</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I read that the senate rejected the bill in the newspaper this morning.
examples.ja: 今朝新聞で上院は議案を否決したって読んだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: "<kanji>No</kanji>" is the <kanji>decision</kanji> I've made. Sorry, but this is <vocabulary>rejection</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I strained my leg when I was out jogging.
examples.ja: ジョギングをしてる時に足の筋を痛めちゃった。

examples.en: It's been a while, but I think I'll try making beef tendon stew again today.
examples.ja: 今日は久々に牛筋のに込みでも作ってみますか。

examples.en: Look, you didn't properly cut the sinew before cooking, so the meat shrank when you grilled it, right?
examples.ja: ほら、肉を焼く前にちゃんと筋を切っておかなかったから焼いたら縮んじゃったでしょ？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, at least on the <kanji>tendon</kanji> side of things.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You get a horrible <vocabulary>tendon</vocabulary> injury, making it so you can't walk anymore. You're so upset that you blame it on Jesus. So, you go and <reading>sue Je</reading>sus for this tendon injury, and win in court, amazingly.

examples.en: I leave work at 7 p.m. every day and then stop by the gym on my way home to develop my muscles.
examples.ja: 毎日七時に仕事を終え、筋肉を鍛えるために帰り道にジムに寄ります。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>muscle</kanji> <kanji>meat</kanji> is your <vocabulary>muscle</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Finally, you drizzle a little olive oil on top like this.
examples.ja: 最後に、こんな感じで、オリーブオイルを少し垂らすんです。

examples.en: A spider dropped a strand of silk from above the balcony and slowly descended.
examples.ja: 一匹のクモがベランダの上から糸を垂らしてゆっくり降りてきた。

examples.en: My nosebleed wouldn't stop, and I dribbled blood all the way home.
examples.ja: 鼻血が止まらず、血をポタポタ垂らしながら帰ってきた。

examples.en: That girl drew a picture of a bulldog drooling while napping and it was super cute.
examples.ja: あの娘がよだれを垂らしながら昼寝しているブルドッグの絵をかいたんだけど、それがすっごく可愛くってさ。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>dangle</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to dangle something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to dribble something</vocabulary>.

垂らす is a transitive verb, so it takes a direct object, as in 糸を垂らす (to hang a line) when fishing. It's also used to describe letting something drip — for example, a little kid letting mucus drip from their nose or a sleeping person dribbling drool out of their mouth.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You're going <vocabulary>to dangle something</vocabulary>, but what? You're going to dangle a <reading>ta</reading>co (た) in front of a hungry person. Kind of a jerk move, honestly. You'll also probably end up dribbling taco sauce all over their shirt, which will earn you double jerk points.

examples.en: I was surprised to see my smartphone standing perfectly upright.
examples.ja: スマホが垂直に立っていてびっくりした。

examples.en: This line is drawn perpendicular to the ground.
examples.ja: この線は地面に対して垂直に引かれている。

examples.en: The ball fell at an almost vertical angle.
examples.ja: ボールは垂直に近い角度で落ちていきました。

meaning_mnemonic: Something <kanji>dangle</kanji>s <kanji>straight</kanji> down, making it perfectly <vocabulary>vertical</vocabulary>. If we wanted to get fancy, we could even say it's <vocabulary>perpendicular</vocabulary> to the floor.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: How much money does Tofugu spend on advertising?
examples.ja: トーフグの広告宣伝費はいくらぐらいですか。

meaning_mnemonic: If you want to <kanji>proclaim</kanji> and <kanji>transmit</kanji> something to a bunch of people, then what better way to do it than <vocabulary>advertising</vocabulary>? Yup, this word refers to various types of <vocabulary>promotion</vocabulary>s, like those for products, services, or ideas. Or, when it comes to transmitting all the things a leader proclaims, you can also call it <vocabulary>propaganda</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: When was the Potsdam Declaration?
examples.ja: ポツダム宣言っていつだっけ？

examples.en: We hereby declare that the long war between the two countries is over.
examples.ja: ここに長きにわたった二国間の戦争が終結したことを宣言します。

examples.en: His favorite idol shocked him and other fans by announcing that she will retire at the end of this year.
examples.ja: 彼のお気に入りのアイドルが、年末に引退するって宣言したから、彼も他のファンもショックを受けちゃってるのよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>proclaim</kanji> things by <kanji>say</kanji>ing them. This is a <vocabulary>proclamation</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>declaration</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My son asked me something like, "How precious is life?" I had difficulty answering him.
examples.ja: 息子に、「命ってどれくらい尊いの？」なんて聞かれちゃってさ。言葉に窮しちゃったよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>revered</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>revered</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: You are <vocabulary>revered</vocabulary> because of your <reading>Toe toe</reading> (とうと), which is a toe on your toe. It's weird, but people seem to like it.

examples.en: The more I know him, the more I respect him.
examples.ja: 彼の事、知れば知る程尊敬するのよね。

meaning_mnemonic: You are <kanji>revered</kanji> and you have my <kanji>respect</kanji>. This is <vocabulary>respect</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Our kids faithfully do what they’re told, unlike yours.
examples.ja: 私達の子どもはあなたの子と違って、忠実に言うことを聞くんです。

meaning_mnemonic: I have <kanji>loyalty</kanji> to you, so I always tell you the <kanji>truth</kanji>. I am very <vocabulary>faithful</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>devoted</vocabulary> to you!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Don’t make light of his advice, or else you might lose your life.
examples.ja: 彼の忠告を侮るでないぞ、さもなくば命を落としかねんぞ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>loyalty</kanji> <kanji>announcement</kanji> is the kind of announcement you give to someone who you're loyal to. To this type of person, your announcement would come in the form of <vocabulary>advice</vocabulary> or maybe <vocabulary>admonishment</vocabulary>, if you're upset with what they've done.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Blood was silently spreading on the floor in a dim room.
examples.ja: 薄暗い部屋の床に、血が静かに拡がっていた。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>extend</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to extend</vocabulary>.

Does the kanji look familiar, kind of like 広い, perhaps? 拡がる is the less common and narrower counterpart of 広がる. It's used to describe the enlargement or extension of the size, area, or range of something.
reading_mnemonic: This word shares the same reading as 広い. That means 拡がる is read as <reading>ひろ</reading>がる.

examples.en: How did you expand your ear piercing hole that much?
examples.ja: どうやってそんなにピアスの穴を拡張したの？

examples.en: I'd like to extend the size of the file.
examples.ja: ファイルのサイズを拡張したいのですが。

examples.en: The Japanese government is debating whether to enlarge Haneda and Narita airports.
examples.ja: 日本政府は、羽田空港と成田空港を拡張するべきか議論している。

meaning_mnemonic: Go ahead and <kanji>extend</kanji> it and <kanji>stretch</kanji> it. That's how we'll do this <vocabulary>enlargement</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>expansion</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>extension</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Of course, just to be dirty, the people who made up this word decided to use a kanji that read as かく. Dirty old monks that could see the future and speak English, ugh.

examples.en: If you click on this button, you can zoom in on Koichi's face.
examples.ja: このボタンをクリックしたら、コウイチの顔が拡大できるよ。

examples.en: Koichi decided to hire an alien to expand Tofugu's business to Mars.
examples.ja: コウイチはトーフグのビジネスを火星まで拡大するため、宇宙人を一人やとうことにした。

examples.en: I enlarged the photo and found out my boyfriend’s nose hairs were sticking out. I was turned off.
examples.ja: 写真を拡大した時に、彼氏の鼻毛が出てることを発見しちゃったんだよね。どん引きだったわ。

With 蒸れる, something gets hot and sticky due to trapped heat and moisture, like sweaty armpits under a shirt on a humid day, or a sticky bottom after sitting at a desk for a while.

Additionally, 蒸れる can mean <vocabulary>to be steamed</vocabulary>, like what happens to rice as it softens in a rice cooker.
reading_mnemonic: What is making things <vocabulary>get hot and sticky</vocabulary>? Not many people know this, but it’s actually all of the cows going <reading>moo</reading> (む). With how much they moo, they create so much steam that everything is turning hot and sticky. Who could’ve known?!

examples.en: We are cleaning our storehouse now.

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Curious about the difference between 蔵 and 倉? Traditionally, the 蔵 kanji was used for sturdy buildings that stored important items. This is where samurai kept their valuables! On the other hand, 倉 originally referred to places to store grain, and usually weren't as robustly made. They're basically interchangeable now, but the 蔵 kanji is more commonly used.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the other storehouse reading you learned earlier with 倉 and 庫. They're all basically the same thing, and lucky for you they share the same reading too (<reading>くら</reading>).

examples.en: You’re already in a spring dress.
examples.ja: もうすっかり春の装いだね。

meaning_mnemonic: This looks like it's an adjective, but it's just a tricky word. It's a noun, and it means the same thing as the kanji, making it <vocabulary>attire</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: "<reading>Yo, so, oh</reading>, you gonna wear that <vocabulary>attire</vocabulary> today or what?"

examples.en: I learned how to use an electrical control device today.
examples.ja: 今日は電気制御装置の使い方を学びました。

meaning_mnemonic: This <kanji>attire</kanji> is <kanji>put</kanji> inside this <vocabulary>equipment</vocabulary>, where it's changed into something else. This attire <vocabulary>device</vocabulary> is strange and interesting. Imagine something that it does to your attire.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I made it to the disguise class at the last minute.
examples.ja: 変装教室にギリギリ間に合いました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Change</kanji> your <kanji>attire</kanji> to look like someone else. This is a <vocabulary>disguise</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I like him, but I'm not really a fan of the way he dresses.
examples.ja: 彼のことは好きなんだけど、服装があまり好きじゃないのよね。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>clothes</kanji> which <kanji>attire</kanji> you is your <vocabulary>attire</vocabulary>. It's how you <vocabulary>dress</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: His story that there is a secret backdoor to her house grew in credibility.
examples.ja: 彼女の家には隠された裏口があるという彼の話は、信憑性を増した。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>backside</kanji> <kanji>mouth</kanji> (think: entrance) is the <vocabulary>back door</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>rear entrance</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 裏 and 口 put together into one word.

examples.en: She betrayed me and I’m feeling depressed.
examples.ja: 彼女に裏切られて落ち込んでいるんです。

examples.en: My friends and I said we would finish the marathon together, but they betrayed me.
examples.ja: 友達と、マラソン大会で一しょにゴールしようねって言ってたのに、裏切られた。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>cut</kanji> someone from the <kanji>backside</kanji> you're doing a backstabbing, making this word <vocabulary>to backstab</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to betray</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 裏 plus 切る put together into one word.

examples.en: When I found out about her betrayal, everything went dark before my eyes.
examples.ja: 彼女の裏切りを知ったとき、目の前が真っ暗になった。

examples.en: Thinking how that kindness was actually just a mask to hide their betrayal made my chest tighten with pain.
examples.ja: あの優しさは、裏切りを隠すための仮面だったのかと思うと、胸がギュッとしめつけられた。

examples.en: Who could've ever imagined that betrayal was lurking behind that angelic smile?
examples.ja: 天使のような笑顔の裏に、裏切りがひそんでいたなんて、誰が想像できただろう。

meaning_mnemonic: From the <kanji>backside</kanji> you <kanji>cut</kanji> someone. Wow. What a jerk. What <vocabulary>betrayal</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>treachery</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This word is 裏 and 切る's readings, put together.

examples.en: The race car sped, weaving through the side streets.
examples.ja: レーシングカーは、裏通りを縫うようにして走っていった。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>backside</kanji> <kanji>street</kanji> (or "avenue") is a street that's not a main street... it's hidden and behind everything, making it an <vocabulary>alley</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 裏 and 通り put together into one word.

examples.en: My profile can be found on the back page of this pamphlet.
examples.ja: 私の紹介はパンフレットの裏表紙に記されています。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji as well.

examples.en: My friends, do you realize this is probably the last time we’ll all be here in the Tofugu office as ten single people?
examples.ja: 諸君、トーフグのオフィスで独身の 10 人がみんな集まるのってこれがたぶん最後だってこと、気がついていたかい？

meaning_mnemonic: My <kanji>various</kanji> <kanji>buddies</kanji>! Wait, that didn't come out right. <vocabulary>Gentlemen</vocabulary>! <vocabulary>My friends</vocabulary>! There we go, much better.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: We are going to pass out various documents to each person present first.
examples.ja: 各出席者の方に、まず諸書類をお配り致します。

meaning_mnemonic: This has the same meaning as the kanji. Stick this onto another word and you have "various _____."
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji as well.

examples.en: If the rent is this much, I might be able to manage living on a small salary.
examples.ja: 安月給だけど、この家賃だったら何とか暮らしていけそうかな。

examples.en: I renewed my contract for the apartment yesterday, but I didn't understand why the rent was $500 more than last year. I thought about moving out for a second.
examples.ja: 昨日、アパートの契約更新したんだけど、去年から家賃が500ドルも上がったってどういうこと？一しゅん引っ越そうかと思ったよ。

examples.en: When I think about the way Fugu treated me, I realized that he was a real jerk. I paid his rent, phone bills, groceries, and everything, but he ended up cheating on me!
examples.ja: フグが私にどんな扱いをしてたか考えてみると、彼がどれだけ最低男だったかが分かるわ。私は彼の家賃から電話代から食費から何から何まで払ってあげていたのに、あの男は他の女と浮気してたのよ！

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>house</kanji> <kanji>rent</kanji> is your <vocabulary>house rent</vocabulary>, though it can be your apartment rent too.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 家 is an exceptional one. It is や, because when your landlord asks if you paid your rent, you always say <reading>yah</reading> (や), whether you did or not.

examples.en: My friend is looking for an apartment to rent, don’t you know any good places?
examples.ja: 友人が賃貸のアパートを探してるんですが、どこかいい物件を知りませんかね。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Rent</kanji> it and I will <kanji>lend</kanji> it to you. This thing that is being lent and rented? It's a <vocabulary>rental</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You just have to remember that 貸 is read as たい for this one. What is your rental? It is a <reading>tie</reading> (たい) fighter. Sweet.

examples.en: Don’t roughhouse in my freighter!
examples.ja: 私の貨物船の中で騒ぐんじゃない！

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>freight</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji>s <kanji>ship</kanji> is a boat that freights things. It's a <vocabulary>freighter</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The 物 takes its もつ reading, which makes sense since it sounds like 持つ, which is "to hold." What is this freighter doing? It's holding freight! So, that's how you can remember that bit.

examples.en: Add three times more flour than water.
examples.ja: お水の三倍の量の小麦粉を入れてください。

examples.en: This is a sweet that is made by kneading flour.
examples.ja: これは小麦粉を練って作ったお菓子です。

examples.en: Oh no. I left the expensive flour I just bought on the train.
examples.ja: うわっ最悪。さっき買った高級小麦粉、電車に忘れちゃった。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Small</kanji> <kanji>wheat</kanji> <kanji>powder</kanji> is <vocabulary>wheat flour</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>flour</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings of all three kanji. The 小 and the 粉 both use kun'yomi that you haven't learned yet, but luckily they are both the same! Just think about how "small" things are like <reading>子</reading> (こ), and "powder" is also small. So both 小 and 粉 are read こ.

examples.en: The training to become a burglar is as hard as boot camp.
examples.ja: 泥棒になるためのトレーニングは、ブートキャンプ並にハードです。

meaning_mnemonic: I don't know why a <kanji>mud</kanji> <kanji>pole</kanji> is a <vocabulary>robber</vocabulary>, but for some reason it is. Just imagine a robber covering himself in mud and standing behind a pole to hide, then jump out, then rob you of everything you've got.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 泥 plus the reading for 棒 put together.

examples.en: The 23-year-old new recruit surprised everyone who works with him by marrying the 82-year-old CEO.
examples.ja: 23歳の新入社員は82歳のCEOと結婚して、一緒に仕事をする人全員を驚かした。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 驚く is "to be surprised"? This is when you are surprising someone else, doing the surprising, making this word <vocabulary>to surprise</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to shock</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 驚く. Don't be surprised if you remember the reading of this word because of your past knowledge.

examples.en: "I’ve been awake since four this morning." "No way! What have you been doing?" "Well, just cleaning around the house."
examples.ja: 「今朝は4時から起きてるよ。」「嘘でしょ？いったい何してるの？」「えっと…家を大掃除してるの。」

meaning_mnemonic: 掃除 is <kanji>cleaning</kanji>, so the verb version would be <vocabulary>to clean</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Also, it'll help to know the word 掃除 as well.

examples.en: I love you so much. I need you. Could you please dry my wet shirts right now, Mr. Sun? Please!!!!
examples.ja: あなたを愛しています。僕にはあなたが必要なんです。太陽さん、どうか僕の濡れたシャツを今すぐ乾かしてくれませんか？お願いします！！！

meaning_mnemonic: 乾く is "to be dried." This is the version where you're doing the drying, making this <vocabulary>to dry something</vocabulary>. You know this because it's annoying to have to dry something yourself, so you <reading>cuss</reading> (かす) endlessly as you do it. "#$@%! Why do I have to waste my time drying this %&$# thing?!"
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 乾く.

examples.en: Why am I so good at making a mess?
examples.ja: 俺、どうしてこんなに散らかすのが得意なんだろう？

examples.en: Every day, I clean up the toys my child scattered before going to bed.
examples.ja: 私は毎日、子供が散らかしたおもちゃを片付けてから寝ます。

examples.en: Leaving trash scattered about is bad manners, you know.
examples.ja: ゴミを散らかしたままにするのは、マナー違反ですよ。

examples.en: Even if I cleaned them up, I would just make a mess again the next day.
examples.ja: 掃除しても、次の日にはまたすぐ散らかしちゃうんだよね。

examples.en: I mean, everyone says "hage-chirakasu" (balding in a scattered, patchy way), but baldness isn't something that "scatters" or that you can "tidy up." That kind of expression is just rude.
examples.ja: いや、みんな「ハゲ散らかす」ってよく言うけど、ハゲは別に「散らかす」も「片付ける」もできないものだから！そんな言い方、失礼だろ。

meaning_mnemonic:
散る is "to be scattered." 散らかす on the other hand is when you're doing the scattering. So it means <vocabulary>to scatter</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to make a mess</vocabulary>.

You often hear it when someone talks about making a room messy or leaving things all over the place. You can remember it easily because after a <reading>ruckus</reading> (らかす), people often leave a mess behind.
reading_mnemonic: The reading of the 散 comes from 散る. So, go ahead and scatter more memories around your brain, you got this already.

examples.en: It's dangerous to take your eyes off your child while swimming!
examples.ja: 水泳中は、子供から目を離すと危ないよ！

examples.en: Shouldn't we put this microwave and toaster a little farther apart from each other?
examples.ja: この電子レンジとトースター、もうちょっと離して置いた方がいいんじゃない？

examples.en: Sorry, I'm in the middle of something. I'll call you back. Okay?
examples.ja: ごめん。いま手が離せないんだ。後でかけ直してもいいかな？

examples.en: That marathon runner is said to have cruised across the finish line, a full hundred meters ahead of the runner-up.
examples.ja: あのマラソン選手は、二番手を百メートルも離して余裕でゴールインしたそうです。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 離れる means "to separate," where something separates or moves away from something else? Well, 離す is the transitive version, so it takes a direct object and means <vocabulary>to separate something</vocabulary>. You can remember this because if you try to separate two people who don't want to be separated, they might sue (す) you in response!

離す is used when you detach or put space between people or objects. This could be literal, like when you 離す your bed from the wall, or more figurative, like when you carelessly 離す your eyes from something important. 

It can also mean <vocabulary>to let go</vocabulary> of something, because you're "separating" your hand from it. This use is very similar to 放す, but it doesn't have that nuance of setting something free — it's just the neutral act of letting go of something.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 離れる.

examples.en: iPads are easier to carry around than laptops.
examples.ja: iPadはノートパソコンよりも持ち運びが簡単です。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Simplicity</kanji> is <kanji>simple</kanji>, making this <vocabulary>simple</vocabulary> as well.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This lawsuit has turned into a quagmire.
examples.ja: この訴訟は泥沼化しています。

examples.en: I got caught up in a messy dispute linked to my friend's divorce.
examples.ja: 友人の離婚の泥沼の争いに巻き込まれてしまった。

examples.en: I saw some green basilisk lizards, known as Jesus lizards, in a marsh in Costa Rica.
examples.ja: コスタリカの泥沼で、忍者トカゲとしても知られているバシリスクを見ました。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>mud</kanji>dy <kanji>bog</kanji> is a way of describing a <vocabulary>quagmire</vocabulary>. It’s a bog with almost no water left, having become all muddy and sticky. Gross (and dangerous)!

This word is typically used figuratively to describe a situation where a conflict becomes messy and difficult to resolve, or a problem from which it is difficult to extricate oneself.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the vocab readings of the two words, 泥 and 沼.

examples.en: Since being designated as editor of the book, I’ve been feeling overworked.
examples.ja: その本の編集者として任命されてから、過労気味です。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>edit</kanji> is 編集. <kanji>Someone</kanji> who does those edits is an <vocabulary>editor</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Also, the readings from 編集 should help you.

examples.en: Didn't you leave supermarket fliers here?
examples.ja: スーパーの散らし、ここに置いてなかった？

meaning_mnemonic: What do people usually scatter in a rush (らし)? Leaflets and flyers. Handing them out takes way too much time, so if you just scatter them all over the place your job will be done so much faster!
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned the 散る, so you should be able to read it already! 

Note that this word is almost always written in kana, and チラシ is much more common than ちらし.

examples.en: It seems that they were attacked by armed insurgents.
examples.ja: どうやら、武装勢力に襲われたようだ。

meaning_mnemonic: The most important part of your <kanji>military</kanji> <kanji>attire</kanji> are your <vocabulary>arms</vocabulary> (not the ones attached to your body, your guns and stuff). Arms are what make you a real military person.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The abnormal weather continues.
examples.ja: 異常気象が続いています。

meaning_mnemonic: When something <kanji>differ</kanji>s from <kanji>normal</kanji> it's called <vocabulary>abnormal</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: There are rumors that the man named Cyrus is actually a robot.
examples.ja: サイラスというあの男は、実はロボットだという噂がある。

examples.en: You really like to gossip, don't you?
examples.ja: あなたって本当、噂をするのが好きね。

examples.en: Do you wanna go to the izakaya "Kagaya" that everyone's talking about online?
examples.ja: ネットで噂の「加賀屋」っていう居酒屋に行かない？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same.
reading_mnemonic: You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

examples.en: My crotch is really itchy.
examples.ja: 股間がすごく痒い。

examples.en: Why does that dancer always put his hand on his crotch?
examples.ja: あのダンサーはどうしていつも股間を押さえるの？

examples.en: It might be embarrassing, but I think you should have your groin looked at by a doctor.
examples.ja: 恥ずかしいかもしれないけど、お医者さんに股間を見てもらったほうがいいと思うよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>groin</kanji> <kanji>interval</kanji> is simply the <vocabulary>groin</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>crotch</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Next up is a stretch for your hip joints.
examples.ja: 次は股関節のストレッチです。

examples.en: I have a really stiff hip.
examples.ja: 私は股関節がすごくかたいんです。

examples.en: I was taught an exercise that will increase blood flow around the hip joint area.
examples.ja: 股関節周りの血流が良くなるエクササイズを教えてもらいました。

meaning_mnemonic: Did you know that your <kanji>crotch</kanji> is <kanji>connected</kanji> via various <kanji>joint</kanji>s? That makes this word your <vocabulary>hip joints</vocabulary> or, more generally, just your <vocabulary>hip</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I'm assuming you are talking about flatulence, am I correct?
examples.ja: あなたは屁の話をしていると思っているんですが、合ってますかね。

examples.en: If I eat pork, I fart a lot.
examples.ja: 私は豚肉を食べると屁がたくさん出ます。

examples.en: Those farts were pretty satisfying.
examples.ja: それらの屁はまあ満足のいくものだったね。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: You already learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be good to go!

examples.en: That's not an illogical argument, it's a fact.
examples.ja: それは屁理屈ではなく事実である。

examples.en: I don't like people who make far-fetched arguments.
examples.ja: 屁理屈をこねる人は嫌いです。

examples.en: Let's stop making lame excuses and get on with what we have to do!
examples.ja: 屁理屈を言うのはやめて、やるべきことをやりましょう。

meaning_mnemonic: You already know 理屈 means "logic" or "argument." So what's <kanji>flatulence</kanji> logic? It's an <vocabulary>illogical argument</vocabulary>, a <vocabulary>far-fetched argument</vocabulary>, or sometimes a <vocabulary>lame excuse</vocabulary>. It's all just hot air!
reading_mnemonic: You've already learned all these readings. You should be able to read this on your own. And no, that's not a far-fetched argument, or a lame excuse for not writing a mnemonic.

examples.en: The Japanese-style taro salad at that izakaya is delicious.
examples.ja: その居酒屋の和風里芋サラダは美味しいよ。

examples.en: What's the best way to preserve taro?
examples.ja: 里芋はどうやって保存するのが一番いいですか？

examples.en: Taro has been eaten in Japan for thousands of years.
examples.ja: 里芋は日本で何千年も前から食べられています。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>hometown</kanji> <kanji>potato</kanji> is a <vocabulary>taro</vocabulary>. In Japan, taro is the kind of potato that everyone has in their hometown, because it's been around for such a long time and it'll grow anywhere.

In English, "taro" can sometimes be used for other root vegetables too, but just keep in mind this word refers specifically to the <vocabulary>Japanese taro</vocabulary> — a small, starchy, potato-like vegetable.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji.

examples.en: If you're going to be a freeloader, you should at least learn to cook.
examples.ja: 居候をするなら、せめて料理くらいは覚えた方がいい。

examples.en: I can't say anything too strongly because I'm staying here for free.
examples.ja: 居候の身だから、あんまり強くは言うことはできないんだよね。

examples.en: So I lost my job and started living as a freeloader.
examples.ja: それで、仕事を失って、居候生活を始めたんです。

meaning_mnemonic: To stay <kanji>alive</kanji> in some <kanji>climate</kanji>s, some have no choice but to be a <vocabulary>freeloader</vocabulary>. That is, <vocabulary>a lodger who pays nothing</vocabulary>. If you live somewhere with an inhospitable climate but you can't afford to pay rent, your only option is to live with someone for free.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a slightly unusual case because both kanji use the kun'yomi. You haven't learned that reading for 候 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

What? You've become a <vocabulary>freeloader</vocabulary>? I can't believe you've gone <reading>so low</reading> (そうろう)!

examples.en: My husband does everything at his own pace and has gentle nature.
examples.ja: 夫はマイペースで、温厚な性格です。

examples.en: That person is usually mild-mannered, but when he gets angry, he's scary.
examples.ja: あの人、普段は温厚だけど、怒らせると怖いよ。

examples.en: If anything, I think I am on the mild-mannered side.
examples.ja: どちらかといえば、オレは温厚なほうだと思う。

meaning_mnemonic:
When a <kanji>warm</kanji> temper is applied extra <kanji>thick</kanji>, it leads to a person having a <vocabulary>mild-mannered</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>gentle</vocabulary> personality.

Note that this is a more formal term, so you'll usually encounter it in writing.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You already know the on'yomi for 温, but not for 厚, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

The most <vocabulary>mild-mannered</vocabulary> Tofugu staff has to be <reading>on</reading>ion <reading>こう</reading>いち. It's an onion that jumps in for こういち whenever he's not at the office. He's the most <vocabulary>gentle</vocabulary> soul you could imagine, never yelling at anyone. The ideal boss, really.

examples.en: This pond has a lot of people swimming in it, it's like a natural pool.
examples.ja: この池はたくさんの人が泳いでて、まるで天然のプールだ。

examples.en: Would you mind buying a bottle of natural water from the convenience store?
examples.ja: コンビニでペットボトルの天然水を買ってきてくれる？

examples.en: Wild eel and yellow tail are quite expensive.
examples.ja: 天然のウナギやブリは高いです。

meaning_mnemonic:
Something of <kanji>heaven</kanji>'s <kanji>nature</kanji> is indeed <vocabulary>natural</vocabulary>, with no human intervention involved.

Although this word is technically a noun, it's often used as an adjective. That's also what distinguishes it from 自然. So you'll often see 天然 used to say that something is "natural" or "of nature", while 自然 will often be used to talk about nature in general, like saying that nature is beautiful.
reading_mnemonic:
You know the reading for 天, but 然 uses a different reading from what you learned. So here's a mnemonic to help you:

One thing that definitely isn't <vocabulary>natural</vocabulary> are <reading>nen</reading>doroids (ねん). Remember, the little plastic figurines? Have you ever seen an anime figurine growing naturally in a field before? Yup, me neither. Not very natural.

examples.en: My child still has the habit of wiping their mouth with their sleeve.
examples.ja: うちの子、まだ口をそでで拭うクセがあるんです。

examples.en: After wiping the blood with his shirt, the man started running again.
examples.ja: 男はシャツで血を拭うと、また走り出した。

examples.en: After gently wiping away her tears with a handkerchief, she stood up as though she had made a resolution.
examples.ja: 彼女はハンカチでなみだをそっと拭うと、決心したように立ち上がりました。

meaning_mnemonic:
You have the kanji for <kanji>wipe</kanji>, and this is the verb version of that, which makes this <vocabulary>to wipe</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to mop up</vocabulary>.

You've already learned 拭く, which is a general word for the act of wiping, whether you're wiping a table or wiping your forehead. 拭う, on the other hand, is more commonly used in writing to describe the act of wiping away and removing something specific like sweat, tears, filth, or even doubts.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a verb, so it uses the kun'yomi. However, to differentiate this verb from 拭く, it uses a different reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember this:

What are you trying <vocabulary>to wipe</vocabulary>? Some <reading>nu</reading>de <reading>goo</reading> (ぬぐ)! You spilled nude goo all over your floor, and now you have to mop it all up… pesky nude goo.

examples.en: I have so many business trips that my miles accumulate really fast!
examples.ja: 出張がたくさんありすぎて、マイルが本当すぐに貯まるよ！

examples.en: As soon as my son has a little pocket money saved up, he goes and buys Pokémon cards at the convenience store.
examples.ja: 私の息子はおこづかいが少しでも貯まると、コンビニにポケモンカードを買いに行くんです。

examples.en: If you don't spend your money while you're alive, it just keeps piling up in the bank — and in the end, you can't take it with you to heaven.
examples.ja: 生きてるうちにお金を使わないと、どんどん銀行に貯まっていくだけだし、結局天国には持っていけないのよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 貯める means "to save up"? This is a lot like that, except the focus is on the thing that's being saved up. That's why it means <vocabulary>to be saved up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to add up</vocabulary>. To remember this is the intransitive version, just think about how it's easy for money to be saved up if you put it in the <reading>mar</reading>ket (まる).

貯まる will often refer to money, like in 資金が貯まる (funds get saved up). But you'll also see it in phrases like マイルが貯まる (frequent flier miles add up).
reading_mnemonic: One thing that tends <vocabulary>to be saved up</vocabulary> is <reading>ta</reading>cos (た). This is because you always make too many tacos, so they have to be saved in the fridge for later. But then you forget about them and make more, so they tend <vocabulary>to add up</vocabulary> even more. It's a vicious taco cycle.
